body:
Comment 2 by **mlhetland**: 
Just what you'd expect. First all false, then a and b (in turn) are set to true. I set
this program up artificially to 
demonstrate which statements are entered and which aren't. The main point is that if you
use either math.Pow() 
or another function containing a call to it, and returning a float64 (in this case the
number 1) directly in the 
condition of an if statement, it'll behave a *bit* like a NaN, but still it won't *be* a
NaN.

I'm attaching an even further simplified version of the program, to highlight the
problem :-)
Attachments: 1. foo.go (179 bytes)
